title: Effects of Resistance Training on Muscular Strength, Endurance, Body Composition and Functional Performance Among Sarcopenic Patients: A Systematic Review

sections.abstract:
Background Sarcopenia, a gradual loss of muscle mass and strength associated with ageing, contributes to a decline in 
physical abilities, increase in disability and frailty and loss of functional independence. This functional deterioration which 
comes with ageing, can be slowed in pace with exercise.
Objective The objective of the current review was to thoroughly search for literature assessing impact of RT on physical 
performance, body composition, muscle strength and endurance in sarcopenic elderly patients.
sections.methods:
PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, and PEDro databases were brought in use for a thorough search for articles 
published from 2010 to 2023. Two researchers independently retrieved data from studies that complied with the inclusion 
and exclusion criteria, while they also evaluated quality of the evidence.
sections.results:
In total, 14 studies with 742 patients with mean age of 72.4 ± 9.22 years were included in the analysis for this review. 
Results indicate, RT improves body composition (p = 0.001), functional performance (p 0.001), postural stability (p = 0.005) 
and muscle strength (p 0.001) in elderly sarcopenic patients.
sections.conclusion:
A promising intervention for the management of sarcopenia is RT. To yield RT’s positive effects, a well-designed 
prescription is the need of the hour, just like it is with other treatment strategies.
Keywords Ageing · Body composition · Frailty · Sarcopenia

sections.introduction:
Sarcopenia is an aging-related condition characterised by 
a generalised, progressive loss of skeletal muscle mass as 
well as a deterioration in muscle performance and strength 
[1]. According to the European Working Group on Sar -
copenia in Older People (EWGSOP), 1 to 29% of people 
over 50 years of age living in community pose sarcopenia, 
compared to 14 to 33% in long-term care facilities and 
10% in acute care facilities [2 ].
In the present times, sarcopenia has established itself 
as a significant global public health concern as, elderly 
population have grown and its associated illness, disability 
and mortality also risen. Sarcopenia is linked to cognitive 
decline [3 ], respiratory [4 ], sleep [5 ], poor quality of life 
and premature mortality [6 , 7]. It also raises the chance 
of unfavourable outcomes including falls and fractures 
[8]. When left untreated, this poses a significant financial 
burden on individuals, families and societies [9 ].Hence, 
sarcopenia should be treated and prevented with promis-
ing care by medical professionals and society, since it is a 
potent predictor of risk for disability, morbidity and mor -
tality among middle- and older-aged adults [10].
The World Health Organization and the American Col-
lege of Sports Medicine (ACSM) with the aim to prevent 
chronic or crippling conditions and/or treat disease, propose 
older people to maintain 150 min per week of moderate-
intensity aerobic exercise or 75 min per week of high-inten-
sity aerobic exercise, and perform RT two to three times per 
week [11, 12]. Previous study data has shown that exercise 
such as Resistance Training (RT), Whole Body Vibration 
Training (WBVT), and Mixed Training (MT, such as RT 
combined with balance and aerobic training), render posi-
tive effect by bringing a increase in muscle mass [13], mus-
cle strength [14], and physical performance [15].
Physical exercise has shown to be a effective therapy 
for halting aging-related loss of muscle mass and strength 
[16]. A supervised exercise program is an successful tech-
nique treating sarcopenia and physical weakness [17, 18]. 
RT may be especially helpful in delaying and reducing 
the cause (such as loss of muscle mass) and consequences 
(such as loss of muscular strength or functionality) that 
these disorders typically induce, even in their early phases 
[19, 20]. RT is characterised as a strength exercise that 
uses progressive loading and requires the muscles to gen-
erate force against an external load [21]. In addition, RT is 
the exercise type intervention that improves physical func-
tion and performance in older adults more than endurance 
training (ET) or WBVT [22]. The well-known benefits of 
Aerobic Training (AT) on health and physical capabilities 
are complemented by RT as a crucial part of a comprehen -
sive exercise programme [23– 25].
RT is the most effective training method for boosting 
muscular development and strength in older individuals 
[26]. It encourages gains in muscle mass and strength, which 
lessens the negative effects of ageing [27]. Studies from the 
past have validate value of RT for sarcopenic older persons. 
With passage of time research on potential benefits of RT 
for age-related physical symptoms is increasing. As a result, 
the state of the art needs to be updated. With older persons 
who have been diagnosed with pre-sarcopenia, sarcopenia, 
pre-frailty, or frailty, this study sets out to carefully assess 
scientific literature examining the impact of RT on mus-
cle strength, endurance, body composition, and functional 
performance.
Methods
Protocols and registration
The present review’s investigation methodology has been 
entered in the PROSPERO database (CRD42023413153). 
The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and 
Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement were followed when con-
ducting the current systematic review and meta-analysis [28].
Identification and selection of studies
Between January 2010 and October 2022, we conducted 
searches in the following significant electronic databases: 
MEDLINE/Pubmed, PEDro, Scopus and Web of Science. 
Only studies in English were taken into account. Medical 
Subject Headings (MeSH) terms such as “sarcopenia,“ 
“RT,“ “muscle weakness,“ “strength training”; “weight-
bearing exercise,“ “strengthening execise,“ “resistive exer -
cise,“ “frail elderly” were used either separately or in com-
bination. The search in the Web of Science and Scopus was 
then conducted using an adaptation of the PubMed syntax. 
Reference list of articles were also searched to find addi-
tional research to be included in the present review. Each 
retrieved publication’s abstract was assessed for its eligi-
bility. For full text analysis, potential suitable articles were 
retrieved. If there was any disagreement, all reviewers came 
together for a consensus conference to decide whether to 
include the publication in the review or to be excluded.
Selection criteria
Inclusion criteria
a) Only randomized controlled or clinical trials were 
included. Studies involving participants over the age 
of 60 years and had pre-frailty, frailty, pre-sarcopenia, 

1055Journal of Diabetes & Metabolic Disorders (2023) 22:1053–1071 
1 3
or sarcopenia without concomitant illnesses (such as 
diabetes, cancer, stroke, dementia, or depression) were 
incorporated. b) RT intervention was to be suggested as 
potential intervention for treating sarcopenia and boost-
ing muscle strength (c) studies involving at least one 
type of RT; (d) a comparison or control group undergo-
ing no exercise or other interventions (such as education 
training); and (e) outcomes involving body composition, 
muscle strength and endurance.
Exclusion criteria
a) Studies involving older individuals with particular ail-
ment were eliminated including those with cancer, dia-
betes, stroke, HIV, chronic obstructive pulmonary dis-
ease, chronic renal disease, liver cirrhosis, other serious 
illnesses, and recent transplants.
b) Studies published as a case report, opinion, editorial, 
protocol, review article, or letter to the editor at a confer-
ence were also excluded.
Data extraction
Papers’ titles and abstracts were separately reviewed by two 
reviewers, who cleared those that not fitting as per the inclu-
sion criteria or the exclusion criteria. Using the inclusion 
and exclusion criteria, the remaining full-text studies were 
assessed. In the event of non-agreement between two review-
ers, a third reviewer took part in the
sections.discussion:
to settle the 
consensus. Using a standard extraction form created for this 
study, two reviewers independently extracted the subject 
characteristics (e.g., demographic parameters), RT inter -
vention (e.g., modality, intensity, frequency, and duration), 
and outcome. We only retrieved the data from intervention 
groups that underwent RT from studies that used multiple-
arm interventions. Authors involved in the present review 
also got in touch with the authors of the featured studies to 
get raw data of participants which was not available in their 
original article.
Methodological quality assessment
Using the Physiotherapy Evidence Database (PEDro) scale, 
two reviewers independently evaluated the included studies’ 
methodology [29]. The scale evaluates the subsequent 11 
traits: ‘Intention to treat’ analysis, between-group statisti-
cal comparisons, point measures or measures of variability, 
baseline similarity, random allocation, concealment alloca-
tion, baseline similarity, blinding of the subjects, therapists, 
and assessors. For each investigation, each feature was given 
a score between 0 (did not meet the requirements) and 1 (sat-
isfied the criteria). The quality of the study increases with a 
higher overall score. When the two reviewers couldn’t agree, 
the third reviewer took part in the assessment and debate.
Data synthesis and analysis
For each outcome that was reported in at least two trials, 
researchers evaluated the presence of these components. 
Control group in the studies used an additional exercise 
modality from the exercise performed in the intervention 
group were classified as quasi-experimental pre-post studies, 
which did not allow for an adequate comparison analysis of 
the effects of exercise but only a within-group analysis and 
discussion.
Risk of bias assessment
Titles and abstracts were initially evaluated by two review -
ers using the inclusion and exclusion criterisa. A 3-point 
scale was used to evaluate the complete text for eligibil-
ity and relevance (0 being not relevant, 1 uncertain, and 2 
being relevant). When agreement could not be achieved, a 
third reviewer was contacted to settle the inclusion contro-
versy. Using the risk of bias 2 (RoB 2) measure developed 
by Cochrane Collaboration, two researchers independently 
evaluated the methodological quality [30]. The instrument 
had five different domains: the randomization procedure, 
variations from intended interventions, missing outcome 
data, outcome assessment, and choice of the reported result. 
The RoB 2 classified each publication as “high risk,“ “some 
concerns,“ or “low risk.“ To obtain a consensus, disagree-
ments in judgements were discussed with a third researcher.
Dealing with missing data
 In the chance of any available individual patient data, 
authors used it when it was not possible to extract metadata 
from a paper. Majority of studies published since 2010 have 
provided the study team with the data needed for the meta-
analysis we are currently doing on individual patient data. 
If data were absent in any other circumstances, we made 
an effort to get in touch with the corresponding author. But 
in the absence of a response, we adhered to the procedures 
indicated in Sect. 7.7.3 of the Cochrane Handbook [31].
Sensitivity analysis
Robustness of the data was assessed using sensitivity analy-
ses to account for the risk of bias items (selection bias, per-
formance bias, attrition bias, and selective result reporting 
bias) as well as the type of contrast. We concentrated on 
selection bias, specifically treatment allocation, among the 
bias risk factors, which comprised a sizable number of ran-
domised trials that were published in the Cochrane Library.

Results
Study selection
According to our search strategy, 1628 records utilis-
ing keywords were found in the searched databases. 1134 
records were extracted following elimination of the duplicate 
records. 876 publications not fitting the selection criteria, 
being excluded after the titles and abstracts being examined. 
Authors read complete texts of the 258 remaining papers 
before further eliminating the 201 that dealt with surgical 
operations. In total, 57 articles were read in their entirety, 
of which 14 had inappropriate methodology, 12 with incor-
rect study design, 4 case reports, 8 news, and 5 with having 
incorrect demographics. Finally, a total of 14 studies were 
included for their detailed analysis. (see Fig. 1).
Demographic study charactertics
Total 14 randomised controlled or clinical trials with 742 
participants were included in the present review. Of these 
14 studies, 3 studies were conducted in Taiwan, 2 in China, 
2 in Italy, 1 in Spain, 1 in Sweden, 1 in Japan, 1 in Brazil, 
1in Switzerland, 1 in Greece and 1 in Germany. Both male 
and females were included with mean age of 72.4 ± 9.22 
years (Table 1).
Main characteristics of study
RT program, when instituted as intervention among elderly 
with sarcopenia served as an effective, reliable and feasible 
method in enhancing functional capability, gaining strength 
and increasing muscle mass and augment physical function, 
thereby, improving their overall quality of life.
Muscle strength & endurance
Findings from a study conducted on elderly Chinese sar -
copenic population revealed resistance exercises when 
incorporated with nutritional supplementation improved 
the participants overall muscle strength. The results sus-
tained up to 12 weeks post-intervention and by 24 weeks, 
also minimal improvements were maintained in leg exten-
sion (P = 0.027) [32].
Impact of various exercise interventions in elderly sarco-
penic population presented with significant improvement in 
muscle strength of knee extensors, back extensor and hand grip 
strength among patients receiving RT when compared to other 
groups (Chen et al., 2017). Findings from a another study, 
involving six weeks of low-repetition, light-load power train-
ing showed improvement in knee extensor muscle strength 
among postmenopausal women with sarcopenia [33].
A 3-month exercise program with a focus on supervised 
RT indicated statistically significant improvement in con-
text to Hand grip strength (HGS) and knee extensor mus-
cle strength post-intervention (Tsekoura M et al.). Another 
study stated participant subjected to 36 weeks of muscle 
reinforcement training, significant increase of HGS values 
only in the RT group (mean ± SD: T0 = 17.84 ± 4.91 kg, 
T1 = 19.86 ± 5.22 kg) [34].
Findings from a study where participants underwent a 
10-week lower limb RT program suggested of improve-
ment in knee extensor muscle power by 15 w/kg on 
average (95% CI 7.5 to 24, P = 0.01) in relation to base-
line values [35]. RT program conducted for sarcopenic 
patients showed a long-term improvement in parameters 
of total grip strength (p = 0.001) and total pinch strength 
(p = 0.014) of the intervention group as compared to the 
control group. Right grip strength of the intervention 
group accelerated by 1.71 kg (p = 0.003) and the left grip 
strength improved by 1.35 kg (p = 0. 028) compared with 
their baseline values [36].
A study on sarcopenic adults subjected to chair muscle 
strength training sessions, performed twice weekly for 3 
weeks showed improvement in self-care scores by 2.76% 
compared to the baseline [37]. Participants in another study, 
receiving a supervised group-based RT program showed 
improved physical function for parameters of locomotion 
(p = 0.006), functionality (p = 0.012), Activities of daily liv-
ing (p = 0.00), and reduction fear reduction (p = 0.013 [15].
Findings from another study indicate significant improve-
ment in functional fitness and physical performance in a 
group of sarcopenic females (F(1,20) = 10.880, p < 0.001, η 
2 p = 0.813) subjected to RT (Bellomo et al., 2013). Muscle 
growth factors such as follistatin were significantly increased 
(p < 0.05, 0.81) among older sarcopenic female performing 
RT thrice weekly over the sixteen weeks (48 sessions) [38].
Body composition
A significant improvement in lower limb muscle mass and 
appendicular skeletal muscle mass was observed in sarco-
penic population subjected to 30-minute RT along with 
nutritional supplementation but the results did not sustain 
to 24 weeks post-intervention [32]. Findings from a study 
where participants underwent RT results showed a consider-
able reduction in percentage body fat, and an increase in the 
muscle mass index 12 weeks post training [39].
A study involving elder sarcopenic population indulged 
in a 60-minute extensive exercise program twice a week for 
three months revealed a significant improvement and result 
sustained up to 24 weeks post intervention [15]. RT regime 
involving motor coordination exercises and muscle toning 
at low-moderate intensity with low weight loads (0.5, 1, or

1.5Kg) led to a significant increase of lean mass and SM 
values from pre- to post-intervention (p < 0.001) [34]. SMI 
increased significantly in the RT group and decreased signifi-
cantly in the CG in elder males with sarcopenia post 12 month 
of training (p < 0.001; SMD = 1.95) [40]. Lean Body Mass 
increased by 1147 ± 282 g (P < 0.001) and Total Fat Mass 
decreased by a mean of 553 ± 25 g (P = 0.003), in 70-year-
old sarcopenic population undergoing RT respectively [41].
Effect of elastic band RT on body composition revealed, 
fat proportion in the right upper extremity (P = 0.03), left 
upper extremity (P = 0.04), total fat (P = 0.035) and fat per-
centage (P = 0.012) had decreased post intervention. Bone 
mineral density (BMD) (P = 0.026), T-score (P = 0.028), 
and Z-score (P = 0.021) elevated post-intervention. Also, 
statistical difference was observed in total fat (P = 0.023) 
and fat percentage (P = 0.012) between the training and con-
trol group. (Huang S.-W. et al.) Findings from another study 
also suggest of increase in BMD in the HIT-RT group and 
results decreased significantly for the CG (p < 0.001) [40].
When community dwelling elderly women with sar -
copenic obesity were subjected to elastic band RT as an 
intervention, showed improvement in their parameters of 
Appendicular Lean Mass (ALM) and appendicular muscle 
index (AMI) post intervention, when compared to their 
baseline scores (P < 0.05). Also, participants they exhibited 
significantly greater changes in total skeletal mass (TSM) 
after training, with a mean difference (MD) of 0.70 kg 
(95% CI: 0.12–1.28; P < 0.01) (Liao C.-D. et al.). Low-
repetition, light-load progressive power training on post-
menopausal sarcopenic women led to an improvement in 
BMD by 1.6% [33].
Biochemical markers
Participants subjected to RT 8 times per week (each session 
lasting 60 min) using weight-training equipment at 60–70% 
of one repetition maximum targeting large systemic muscle 
groups demonstrated remarkable improvement in blood IGF-1 
concentration 8 weeks post-intervention [39].
Gait parameters
A 10-week progressive RT program, holding 3 sessions 
per week and each session lasting 45 min suggested of sig-
nificant improvement in functional outcome scores in SBBP 
(P < 0.05), TUG time (P < 0.001) [41]. In another study, a 
group of participants receiving elastic RT using Thera-band, 
walked faster by 0.14 m/s (P < 0.05), spent a short span of time 
for 1.64 s (P < 0.001) in the Timed Up & Go (TUG) test and 
completed 2.99 more repetitions (P < 0.001) of the timed chair 
rise (TCR) task than the control group (Liao C.-D. et al.). Gait 
analysis among participants receiving 12 weeks of RT showed 
significant increase in length of the half-step post intervention 
(108%; P < 0.05) [42].
Balance
A physical activity program based on resistance exercises 
performed twice a week, for 36 weeks with each session last-
ing for 60 min confirmed, significant decrease in sway path 
acquired with closed eyes (Z = 3.53, p < 0.001). Also, sway 
area (with both eyes open and closed) decreased significantly 
after the treatment (CE: Z = 5.01, p < 0.001). Findings con-
cluded that RT to be an effective approach in reducing falls 
among elderly sarcopenic women [34].
Based on the results obtained from another study, con -
ducted on women with sarcopenic obesity and receiving RT, 
outcome suggested of an improvement in overall balance, 
measured via an increase in scores of functional forward reach 
(FFR) task, reaching further by 7.46 cm (P < 0.001) and main-
taining balance in single leg stance for a longer time of 9.71 s 
(P < 0.001) [43].
Quality of life
Findings from a study where participants received RT and 
nutritional supplementation suggested reduction in impair -
ments of daily activity tended to be greater in the combined 
group (RT and nutritional supplementation) than the other 
two groups (RT alone, control group) at 12-week assess-
ment (P = 0.055). However, the reduction was not sustained 
at 24-week assessment [32] (Tables  2 and 3, Figs. 2, 3, 4 
and 5).
Discussion
Parameters evaluated
With research being done, still there lacks research on the 
benefits of RT for sarcopenic older adults towards good 
health. With the aim to segregate how RT affects body 
composition, muscle strength, endurance and functional 
performance in older persons with sarcopenia authors in 
this review integrated 14 randomised controlled trials. The 
pooled studies revealed, RT significantly improves body fat 
mass, handgrip strength, knee extension strength, endurance, 
gait speed, and time to stand and go, when compared to no 
exercise or non-exercise activities but, they have no appre-
ciable impact on skeletal muscle mass, leg lean tissue, or 
appendicular skeletal muscle mass index. Earlier findings 
suggest RT may have positive impact on sarcopenia-related 
outcomes p < 0.001) and lower-limb (ES = 0.93, p < 0.001) 
strength [39, 42, 44].

Structured physical activity and sarcopenia
There is evidence in favour of structured physical activity 
interventions to prevent onset of disability among older 
people and improving clinical outcomes such as physical 
performance, walking speed, overall survival, fall risk and 
quality of life [45]. So far, there are heterogeneous findings 
regarding the effect of exercise interventions to preserve 
functional fitness, including sarcopenia [46]. Sarcopenia 
is highly correlated in leading to side effects of poor qual -
ity of life and reduced performance in activities of daily 
life [47, 48], but most importantly, it increases the risk of 
falls and fractures [49].Loss of muscle strength may also 
be significant cause of postural instability [50] and thus 
represents an inherent fall risk factor reducing the ability 
to fall older adults to respond appropriately to unexpected 
disturbances and successfully restore balance [51– 53].
Effects on muscle mass
It is well documented favouring low muscle mass indepen-
dently predict slip [54], fractures, and general ill health, 
including death [55]. Thus, there is interest in creating a 
personalised physical training regimen that could increase 
muscle mass and strength in elderly people who are fee-
ble. In both younger and older people, RT is believed 
to primarily build muscle strength, initially through 
neuromuscular adaptation [56]. The observation of an 
increase in muscle mass after only 10 weeks of exercise 
was a surprising but an encouraging finding reported. As 
a result, older persons who participate in RT programmes 
often experience limited effects on muscular hypertrophy, 
and these effects appear to be impacted by ageing [41, 56].
RT and body composition
It’s challenging for elderly people to use RT to alter body 
composition. Despite the fact that patients could main-
tain lean body mass after exercise training, it was found 
that the differences in skeletal muscle mass between study 
groups were statistically nonsignificant [57, 58]. The pri-
mary factor causing this outcome may be the length of 
training. According to a previous study, resistance induces 
minor impact on body fat, nevertheless, and was consistent 
with prior interventional trials [59]. Adipogenic cells and 
muscle development are subject to pathological change, 
but the exact processes are still unknown [59, 60].
Effects on muscle physiology, endocrine function and fat
RT brings to stimulation in muscle protein synthesis, expand 
type 1 and type 2 muscular fibres, and enhance total muscle 
strength and athletic performance in older individuals with 
sarcopenia [61]. Body size and muscle mass are fundamen-
tally related to each other. The impact of RT on body fat

with sarcopenia, RT was found to dramatically reduce body 
fat. RT can considerably reduce body fat in older adults 
with SO, according to Hsu et al.‘s meta-analysis, which is in 
line with our findings [63]. Due to the fact that strength and 
performance in older persons, particularly in women, decline 
more quickly than muscular mass, muscle strength and per-
formance are crucial for independent living and active ageing 
[64].
Impact on muscle strength and functional 
performance
We discovered that use of RT intervention considerably 
improved all of the analysed functional capacities (p < 0.05). 
All article documented benefits from RT. Additionally, all 
studies also revealed RT group with better results in terms 
of improvement of functional tasks. These results might be 
closely related to notable increases in lower-limb strength. In 
general, exercise programmes are successful in lowering sever-
ity of frailty and sarcopenia [17]. Our findings are in line with 
earlier research showing that RT improves muscular strength 
and physical function in older adults with frailty or sarcopenia 
(Bao et al., 2020; De Mello et al., 2019; Lopez et al., 2018). 
However, those earlier studies did not combine the two syn-
dromes (sarcopenia and frailty), and if they did, they looked at 
the overall impact of exercise [65]. These new findings add to 
the growing body of research highlighting RT, as opposed to 
endurance training or whole-body vibration training and other 
forms of training, to significantly improve muscle strength and 
physical performance in older persons [22].
Sarcopenia and physiological responses
Physiological responses to anabolic stimuli can be compro-
mised in older adults. First, as people get older following 
diverse reasons. To begin with the mediation mechanisms 
between exercise and improvements in muscular function 
becomes typically weakened or delayed. Age-related altera-
tions to the endocrine, immune, and metabolic systems show 
frequent dysfunctional or maladaptive reactions to the stimu-
lus of exercise [66, 67]. Additionally, obesity worsens the 
pro-inflammatory state that comes with ageing and interferes

Fig. 4 Forest plot for Body fat

1068 Journal of Diabetes & Metabolic Disorders (2023) 22:1053–1071
1 3
with the function of adipose and muscle cells [68– 70]. The 
same outcomes that are seen in other populations of older 
women must be observed [71, 72]. After RT training, all of 
these characteristics may make it more challenging for older 
women with SO to increase muscular performance [35]. In 
a study, the majority of individuals were physically active 
and performed quite well on mobility tests. A ceiling effect 
might have stopped these results from significantly improv-
ing. Furthermore, due to the interaction of many health 
issues in clinical trials with older participants, functional 
outcomes are typically challenging to detect [73]. RT has 
been found to have less of an impact on quality of life and 
physical function than on muscle performance [36, 37]. In a 
prior study, the quality of life measurement using the SF-36 
may have been impacted by the similar ceiling effect. To see 
a substantial improvement in these outcomes, the suggested 
RT intervention’s duration, intensity, and frequency should 
be varied [35].
Multidisciplinary approach for sarcopenia 
management
Exercise regimens are frequently brief in practised but gener-
ally patients stop participating after few sessions. In order to 
optimise potential advantages of RT, strategies that priortized 
continuous involvement among older persons with sarcope-
nia are required. The promotion of positive messages about 
RT involves everyone who is involved in the care of elderly, 
including family members, carers, and health and care profes-
sionals (such as physiotherapists, physicians, and dieticians). 
The creation of care pathways is also required to enable the 
implementation of RT as a sarcopenia treatment. Our guidelines 
may be best used by specialised healthcare experts, such as a 
physiotherapist, to evaluate, design, and review safe and effi-
cient RT programmes. As with the delivery of exercises for fall 
prevention, delivery could be done in collaboration with other 
rehabilitation specialists working in healthcare and community 
settings. This strategy might encourage ongoing development 
and sustained engagement, but it would be necessary to recog-
nise and solve participation constraints like accessibility [74]. 
In addition to above best results in professional practise should 
also hold a holistic assessment in older adult’s health, physical 
limitations, motivation, and personalised goal setting [75].
Limitations
The present review also pose limitations. To begin with, most 
variables showed moderate to high levels of heterogeneity, 
making meta-analysis challenging, with the exception of the 
functional strength and fat mass. This finding may be pri-
marily explained by the variety of variables employed in the 
quantitative evaluation (i.e., clinical heterogeneity) as well 
as the variety of approaches (i.e., volume, intensity, exercise, 
programme duration) used in each study. Furthermore, while 
the average duration of the training interventions in the pre-
sent review enables us to hypothesise that RT is an operational 
short- to medium-term strategy, more evidence, including 
longer RT programmes, is required to confirm the long-term 
benefits, particularly whether they are effective for lowering 
the prevalence of sarcopenia and frailty.
Future recommendations
Future randomised controlled trials and reviews are highly 
encouraged towards investigating effect of RT on other physi-
ological parameters, with a focus on exercise duration, repeti-
tions, and intensity, in individuals with pre-sarcopenia, sarco-
penia, pre-frailty, or frailty. These parameters include neural 
drive, muscle architecture, muscle function, or tendon propri-
eties. As mentioned, there is still a critical need for quantita-
tive and qualitative research including older people who have 
Fig. 5 Forest plot for functional strength

1069Journal of Diabetes & Metabolic Disorders (2023) 22:1053–1071 
1 3
been diagnosed with sarcopenia in order to strengthen the 
body of knowledge in this field. There is also need for more 
thorough interventions and trials that last longer and include 
extensive follow-up times.
Clinical application
RT for the elderly has been summarised in the current review, 
which clinicians and exercise practitioners should incorporate 
while designing treatment of older persons with sarcopenia 
and achieve favourable outcomes. To fully realisebenefits of 
RT as a treatment for sarcopenic older persons, number of 
factors are to be taken into account. It is important to con-
sider how to recognise older persons likely benefited from RT 
[20]. A useful and quick way to determine who has probable 
sarcopenia is to evaluate muscle strength (e.g., grip strength 
or the chair stand test, Timed up and go test etc.). Sarcope -
nia, however, is not typically evaluated in clinical practise. In 
this context, opportunistic screening in primary care (such as 
yearly physicals) and identifying risk factors (such as older 
age, those needing oral steroid therapy, history of falls, low 
physical activity, and multimorbidity) may be helpful [76].
Conclusion
A promising intervention for managing sarcopenia is RT. A 
well convinced prescription is needed to optimise RT’s posi-
tive effects, just like it is with other treatment approaches. 
RT should be prioritized to delay and reduce the detrimental 
effects of sarcopenia and frailty in both early and late stages.
